awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Economics: The Effect of Access on Beliefs
awd_abstract_narration:
Although governments, academics and policy-makers agree about the large benefits of education in societal outcomes, investment in education amongst the poor remains low. One reason, cited by researchers in economics, is that poor people have low expectations about the value of education when compared to estimates from data. Another potential explanation is psychological. Work in sociology finds that poor families have more pessimistic outlooks on the future value of education due to obstacles like low quality schools, larger financial constraints and racial discrimination. Perhaps most striking, recent empirical studies find that providing poor people access to resources increases their expectations on the value of education, despite no information being provided about the value per se.

Building on these findings, one possible theory is that low expectations help individuals cope with low access to an investment. Rather than lamenting a small chance to make a potentially life-changing investment, individuals feel better by underestimating its value, a theory called "the sour grapes effect".  The goal in this project is to utilize the economic tools of a laboratory setting to explore this effect, and the relationship between access and beliefs more broadly. The lab provides a clear methodological advantage as empirical studies to date suffer from likely confounds.

The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in attempting to study a real-world problem with a novel psychological intuition that can be framed using rigorous theory and investigated through experimental methodologies. The research agenda is grounded in the theory of decision-making under ambiguity and may document a new violation of (Subjective) Expected Utility theory.

The research agenda makes some important contributions and has potentially broader impacts. Exploring the access-based beliefs could increase our understanding of how perceived (not estimated) beliefs of the returns to education are formed, an important determinant of schooling decisions. Furthermore, access-based beliefs may be the source of a cycle of low access, and investment that traps people in poverty. Lastly, they would suggest a novel pathway for the efficacy of social programs that expand access to public goods, namely that optimistic beliefs may play an important role. Ultimately, research that furthers our knowledge on how subjective beliefs on the returns to investment are formed can help create better models of decision-making under uncertainty and inform policy-makers in a variety of contexts.

por.por_cntn:
The project explores a notion called ''access-based beliefs'', the idea that access to an alternative has a direct impact on beliefs of its value. As an example, individuals may make themselves feel better by lowering beliefs of alternatives to which they have limited access, a phenomenon colloquially known as sour grapes. Such sour grapes may provide a potential explanation for a long-lasting puzzle in low-income settings, which is that poor people underinvest in high return technologies like education, healthcare, migration. A proposed explanation in the literature has been that due to a lack of information, poor people have low  (directly-elicited) subjective expectations of the return to these investments when compared to estimates from data. The theory of access-based beliefs proposes instead that individuals may systematically hold low beliefs of the returns to these potentially life-changing investments as a means of coping with the sadness of low access, a mechanism that impacts the level of investment.

The main goal of this project is to provide the first robust evidence of access-based beliefs. The challenge is that in most real-world scenarios, changes in access are accompanied by changes in people's information, and under standard economic theory, any correlation between access and beliefs may simply reflect learning. Additionally, access is endogenous and may itself serve as a signal of an object's value. To tackle these issues, the project's main contribution is to provide evidence for access-based beliefs in a lab and field setting where learning is precluded. For this project, access is defined generally and parsimoniously as the probability that an option is in a choice set.

In the lab, participants are exogenously assigned either a low or high chance of being paid out by a two-outcome, subjective lottery whose distribution of outcomes is unknown. Before uncertainty is resolved, revealed beliefs of the subjective lottery are elicited using an incentivized elicitation task in which choices between the subjective lottery and an objective lottery (whose distribution of outcomes is known) are made. The main result is that a 60 p.p. reduction in access to the subjective lottery lowers beliefs of the high outcome by 3 p.p. (.2 standard deviations), consistent with the sour grapes hypothesis. Furthermore, the effect appears to exist only for individuals who are initially optimistic about the subjective lottery, that is, who have beliefs of a high payout greater than 50%. This is consistent with the intuition that those who really desire the alternative are the ones who engage in sour grapes to cope with low access.

The lab findings are corroborated in the real world using data from an existing field experiment in which access to a free, commercially available SAT prep course was randomized in low and high-income public schools in Los Angeles (Bursztyn, Egorov, and Jensen, 2017).  The main result is that a 50 p.p. drop in the probability of receiving the package, conditional on signing up, leads to a 50% reduction (.2 standard deviations) in expected returns of the prep package, consistent with the sour grapes effect found in the lab. Low access also appears to have effects on actual decisions for a group of individuals who likely have a high valuation for the package: high achieving students in the low-income school are 18% less likely to sign up for the package reduce when given low access.  

Additionally, there is suggestive evidence of access-based beliefs being more prevalent amongst the poor; in both the lab and field, sour grapes effects are larger for individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds and lower income settings. This has implications for the broader impacts of this project, that is, access-based beliefs may be strongest for individuals for whom the needs and returns on investment might be the largest. Critically, access-based beliefs may be at the root of a psychological poverty trap where low access to investments leads to low beliefs of their value, thus fostering even lower access. This project highlights the crucial role that access-improving interventions can play and an additional psychological mechanism by which increasingly popular programs like direct income transfers may be so effective.
